trial_identification.studytitle: Clinical Pilates as a catalyst for engaging the aging
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Benefit to postural balance using Clinical Pilates exercises for healthy older adults

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions: 2 Sessions per week in clinic and one home based session for 6 weeks for 45-60 minutes of Clinical Pilates exercise (ie 18 sessions in all). Clinic sessions using a Pilates reformer and mat work work will be supervised by a qualified physiotherapist. Four participants per session will allow individualisation of the exercise program, which will target leg strength and balance. The home program will consist of similar exercises to the mat work. Four weeks of washout will be undertaken before these participants will embark upon the contorl arm of the study.
interventions.comparator: This first arm of this study included a control group that consisted of normal activity for six weeks, wash out for four weeks, and then participation in the exercise intervention for six weeks. The next stage of recruitment will be for a RCT. It will run for ten weeks, during which the control group will be requested to maintain usual activity. Participants allocated to the control group will have the opportunity to participate in the treatment intervention after the study is completed if they request.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Functional mobility will be measured using Timed up and go
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, Post intervention, Post washout, end of second intervention.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Postural balance will be measured by mediolateral postural sway
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, Post intervention, Post washout, end of second intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Fall rate will be measured prospectively using a falls diary.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, Post intervention, Post washout, end of second intervention 12 months post intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Lung volumes will be measured using the clinical measure of Vital Capacity using a spirometer (Pony brand).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, at the end of 5 weeks and again at ten weeks

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Independently mobile community dwelling older adults
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Musculoskeletal injury Recent unstable medical conditions that would preclude exercise

trial_design.concealment: At enrollment each particpant will be allocated a number. The allocation of numbers to active or treatment group will be performed by a central administrator who will hold the allocation schedule.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomization table created by a computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this project is to assess the effect of a clinical Pilates intervention in community dwelling older adults on balance, strength, range of movement and blood glucose. A variety of exercise programs have been found to be beneficial in addressing physiological parameters (blood glucose control, lipid profile control, cardiovascular health) and biomechanical parameters (balance, range of movement and strength) but this form form of exercise had been little studied. Pilates is a popular form of exercise that proposes a range of health benefits, although the research into physiological and psychological benefits is limited.
